results.question: What is the definition of deferred revenues?
gold_answer: Performance obligations for which payments have been received by the customer prior to revenue recognition.
results.markdown_table_response: Deferred revenues are revenues that have been recognized in the period in which they have been received, but are not yet recognized in the period in which they are earned or will be earned. Deferred revenues may be subject to future changes in estimates, if any, that may affect the timing or amount of payments. Deferred revenues consist primarily of deferred software and deferred subscription-based services. Deferred software performance obligations are those amounts allocated to mobile dashboard and on-line apps and unspecified upgrade rights. Deferred subscription-based services performance obligations are those amounts allocated to mobile dashboard and on-line apps and unspecified upgrade rights.
results.csv_string_response: Deferred revenue is the amount that has been allocated to the customer prior to revenue recognition and which is included in the period's revenue for the following period, whether or not the customer has satisfied the performance obligations. The deferred revenue is the difference between the customer's initial outlay and the customer's cost for the performance obligations. Deferred revenue consists of software, or amounts allocated to mobile dashboard and on-line apps and unspecified upgrade rights. Deferred revenue also includes deferred subscription-based services. The deferred software and deferred subscription-based service performance obligations are anticipated to be recognized over the useful life or service periods of one to eighteen months.
results.json_rows_response: Deferred revenues are revenue that has been recognized for which the customer has made a payment. Examples include subscriptions, upgrades, and payments for the license of a product. Revenue that has been recognized for which the customer has made a payment should not be considered deferred until the payment has been made. This includes software, mobile dashboard and on-line apps, and unspecified upgrade rights.

results.question: How does a non-employee director receive his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant?
gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
results.markdown_table_response:
This section explains how a non-employee director receives his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant.
A non-employee director is appointed to the board after any annual meeting of stockholders. The board will typically choose to appoint the non-employee director at the same time as the annual meeting.
The board will typically award a restricted stock unit award or option grant at the time of the appointment. The restricted stock unit award or option grant is not expected to be liquidated until the director reaches a particular age, and then the restricted stock unit award or option grant is expected to be fully liquidated within the year in which the director reaches that age.
The amount of the restricted stock unit award or option grant is typically equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant.
The board will typically use a grant date fair value method to determine the grant date fair value of the restricted stock unit award or option grant. The grant date fair value of the restricted stock unit award or option grant is calculated as the value of the award or grant on the grant date plus the estimated forfeitures over the remaining vesting period.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
Basic EPS is computed by dividing net loss by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

results.question: Why was the disallowance of the shorter deductibility period would not affect the annual effective tax rate but would accelerate the payment of cash to the taxing authority to an earlier period?
gold_answer: Because of the impact of deferred tax accounting
results.markdown_table_response: For tax purposes, the impact of deferred tax accounting is that the period of potential tax benefits is shorter than it is in the income statement. For example, if a company has $1.0 million of unrecognized tax benefits at fiscal year-end, and a taxing authority has a period of potential tax benefits of five years, the period of potential tax benefits is five years. In the income statement, however, the period of potential tax benefits is only two years. Therefore, the impact of deferred tax accounting is that a company will have to pay tax on its deferred tax assets (and liabilities) earlier than it would have in the income statement. However, the effective tax rate will not be affected by the time at which the deferred tax assets and liabilities are paid.
results.csv_string_response: Because the deferred tax assets and liabilities were recognized in the Consolidated Statements of Operations under the historical cost method, the effect of the accounting change was that the deferred tax assets and liabilities were recognized in a manner that was more favorable than the tax basis used in the determination of income tax expense.
results.json_rows_response: The final answer is that the carryforwards, which gave rise to significant portions of deferred tax assets and liabilities, resulted in deferred tax assets and liabilities. The liability for the carryforwards was deductible over a longer period than the liabilities. The deductible portion of the liability was recognized in the consolidated financial statements of the consolidated reporting entity as of the earlier of the date the assets or liabilities are recognized and the date that the annual effective tax rate is expected to be materially different from the effective tax rate that would have been used had the carryforwards been included in income for the respective periods.

We also use certain non-GAAP financial measures, including Adjusted EBITDA, as performance measures under our executive bonus plan. Further, we believe the exclusion of certain expenses in calculating Adjusted EBITDA facilitates comparisons of our operating performance on a period-to-period basis and, in the case of exclusion of acquisition-related expense and certain historical legal expenses, excludes items that we do not consider to be indicative of our core operating performance. Accordingly, we believe that Adjusted EBITDA provides useful information to investors and others in understanding and evaluating our operating results in the same manner as our management and board of directors.
Our use of Adjusted EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool, and you should not consider it in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our financial results as reported under GAAP. results.question: What is the $ change in the capital expenditures for Bell Wireless?
results.markdown_table_response:
CAPITAL EXPENDITURES
BCE capital expenditures totaled $669 million for the year, up $33 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 6.0%, down 0.1 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

Share-based Compensation Our Board of Directors may grant share-based awards from our shareholder approved Amended and Restated Consolidated Communications Holdings, Inc. 2005 Long-Term Incentive Plan (the “Plan”). The Plan permits the issuance of awards in the form of stock options, stock appreciation rights, stock grants, stock unit grants and other equity-based awards to eligible directors and employees at the discretion of the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors.
On April 30, 2018, the shareholders approved an amendment to the Plan to increase by 2,000,000 the number of shares of our common stock authorized for issuance under the Plan and extend the term of the Plan through April 30, 2028.
With the amendment, approximately 4,650,000 shares of our common stock are authorized for issuance under the Plan, provided that no more than 300,000 shares may be granted in the form of stock options or stock appreciation rights to any eligible employee or director in any calendar year. Unless terminated sooner, the Plan will continue in effect until April 30, 2028.
